off.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: He got into his car and drove off.
Suddenly they turned off and parked in a side road.
Once we were off the main freeway, the trip felt more like a vacation.
Her husband was off on a business trip somewhere.
Are you ready? Off we go.
I must be off now  (=I must leave).
They were off to Italy  (=leaving to go to Italy) and wanted to make an early start.
off.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: not on something, or removed from something
off.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: As he leaned forward, his hat fell off.
Someone had taken the mirror off the wall.
I was trying to scrape the mud off my boots.
off.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: out of a bus, train, plane etc
off.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: I’ll get off at the next stop.
Everyone got off the train at Winnipeg.
off.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: a machine, piece of equipment etc that is off is not working or operating
off.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: Will someone switch the radio off?
Make sure all the lights are off.
off.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: not at work, school etc because you are ill or on holiday
off.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: My secretary’s been off with flu for the past week.
Clare had to stay off school because her mother was ill.
You look tired. Why don’t you take tomorrow off?
He needs more time off duty for relaxation and rest.
‘Going to work today, mum?’ ‘No. It’s my day off today.’
off.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: My brother once borrowed some money off him.
I got this necklace off a woman outside the market.
off.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: used to say how far away something is
off.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: We could see the cliffs of Shetland about two miles off.
Kara’s home was a long way off across the sea.
off.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: used to say how much time there is between now and a future event
off.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: With the exams now only a week off, I had to study hard.
Christmas seemed a long way off.
off.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: used to say how likely or unlikely something is
off.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: Any kind of peace agreement still seems a long way off.
off.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: only a short distance away from a place
off.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: Our hotel was just off the main street.
an island off the coast of France
off.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: connected to a particular room, area, road etc
off.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: There’s a small bathroom off the main bedroom.
a narrow street leading off the corner of the square
off.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: used to say that a price is reduced by a particular amount
off.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: If you buy more than ten, they knock 10% off.
off.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: if an event which has been arranged is off, it will not now take place
off.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: The race may have to be called off if the bad weather continues.
off.translation[0].definitions[13].defin: behaviour that is off is rude or is not acceptable
off.translation[0].definitions[13].examp: She walked out before the end of your lecture, which I thought was a bit off.
Look, I know when someone’s being off with me.
off.translation[0].definitions[14].defin: used to say how much of something someone has
off.translation[0].definitions[14].examp: How are you off for sports equipment (=do you have enough?)?
The school’s fairly well off for books these days.
off.translation[0].definitions[15].defin: no longer wanting or liking something
off.translation[0].definitions[15].examp: Toby’s been off his food for a few days.
I used to enjoy tennis, but I’ve gone off it a bit now.
She seems to have gone off Mark since he’s grown a beard.
off.translation[0].definitions[16].defin: no longer taking something such as a drug or medicine
off.translation[0].definitions[16].examp: The operation was a success, and she’s off the morphine.
off.translation[0].definitions[17].defin: food that is off is no longer fresh enough to eat
off.translation[0].definitions[17].examp: Do you think the meat’s gone off?
off.translation[0].definitions[18].defin: used to say that a particular kind of food is not available in a restaurant although it is on the menu
off.translation[0].definitions[18].examp: I’m sorry, the fish pie is off today, sir.
off.translation[0].definitions[19].examp: Sales figures for last year were a little off compared with those of the previous year.
off.translation[0].definitions[20].examp: Guess again. You’re way off (=very far from being correct).
off.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: used to talk about a pair of things such as wheels on a car, to mean the one on the right
off.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: The guy who did this ought to be offed.
